creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: female figure in elaborate head dress, PL hand in gesture near chest, riding on a fox; fox is flying on green cloud with legs extended; snakes wrapped around fox's legs; two smaller figures kneeling in foreground
text: The figure of Dakiniten in this scroll exemplifies Buddhism’s ready assimilation of native gods. The deity entered the Buddhist canon as a converted Hindu goddess, and is shown riding a fox—the messenger of the Shinto kami, or deity, known as Inari. The fox’s legs are wrapped in snakes, a reference to another converted Hindu goddess, Benzaiten.
title: Dakiniten, the Buddhist Manifestation of the Shinto Deity Inari
